sect1.title: Impact of Gender, Race, Culture, Age, and Other Aspects of Diversity
sect1.para: Multiple dimensions of diversity impact the assessment of depressive disorders, including race and ethnicity, immigration status, gender, sexual orientation, socioeconomic status, and age. A thorough review of diagnostic considerations for each diverse group is beyond the scope of this chapter; rather, the focus is on general considerations and strategies. Moreover, there are significant individual differences within groups that require a flexible, individualized approach to diagnostic interviewing. The individual’s background likely impacts the assessment process from the first encounter, as the clinician strives to build trust, rapport, and socialize the individual to the assessment process. As the assessment progresses, the client’s background may influence how symptoms are reported, observed, and conceptualized, for which the clinician needs to consider the validity of standardized assessment tools being used and additional cultural factors to assess. Finally, depressive symptoms occur in the context of other biopsychosocial considerations, which inform the clinician’s case conceptualization and treatment planning.

sect2.title: Rapport Building and Education About the Assessment Process
sect2.para: Three strategies during the initial rapport-building phase may mitigate these concerns and maximize information gathering with older adults and diverse groups: (1) carefully informing the client of the purpose of the assessment and what to expect during the assessment process, (2) reducing stigma through empathetic responses, and (3) practicing cultural humility and maintaining cultural competence to facilitate the rapport-building process. First, it is important to ascertain the clients’ understanding of why they are seeing the clinician and to provide them with all relevant information about the purpose of the assessment. Similarly, the interviewer should inform clients about what to expect, such as length of the assessment, types of information that will be sought, rationale for the information being asked of the client, from whom information will be sought (including gathering appropriate permissions), and how the assessment results will be used and reported back to the client. Some clients may be concerned about the outcomes of the assessment (e. g., hospitalization, competency or legal issues) or concerned about the protection of their confidentiality, so the clinician needs to carefully discuss the potential outcomes of the assessment and what information will be shared with whom.

Stigma concerns may be reduced by empathizing with the client’s symptoms or situation, viewing distress as common or understandable in some difficult situations. For example, while assessing mood symptoms with an older caregiver who has recently placed their partner in a long-term care facility, the clinician may note that caregivers often feel guilty, worrying that they “didn’t do enough,” thus normalizing and recognizing the difficult emotions involved in caregiving and role transitions. This may allow the caregiver to further open up more about experiences of guilt as well as other depressive symptoms.

sect2.title: Use of Standardized Assessment
Supplementing Standardized Assessment with a Cultural Formulation
sect2.para: The CFI begins by asking about the patient’s (or informant’s) perspective regarding the presenting problem, its causes, helpful supports, and stressors that make the problem worse. The next set of questions asks about the patient’s cultural identity and how it relates to their problems. Subsequent questions ask about coping strategies the patient has tried and how the patient has sought help (formal or informal) from others. The final questions ask about preferences for future assistance and any concerns or observations the patient has about their relationship with the clinician. The questions are written in plain language, with instructions that there is no “right” answer, and include definitions for some terms.

sect2.title: Biopsychosocial Assessment
sect2.para: Individuals from underserved populations frequently have complex, multidimensional problems associated with a depressive disorder. Such problems may include physical illness and limitations, limited income, poor social support networks, and unsafe or unstable housing situations situations . These individuals also may view depressive symptoms in relation to these other difficulties, complicating the identification of symptoms. For example, a client who is unemployed and of low income may primarily discuss their concerns related to job-seeking, rather than their mood symptoms. Alternatively, an older adult may talk about their loneliness rather than depression. Thus, to fully explore depressive symptoms and develop a comprehensive treatment plan, the clinician needs to conduct an assessment of the clients’ multidimensional needs.

Older adults with depression have been found to experience significantly more unmet needs across multiple domains (environmental, physical, psychological, social) compared to older adults without depression (Stein et al., 2016 ), underscoring the importance of supplementing mood evaluations with an assessment of other needs. In fact, addressing the multidimensional needs of older adults adults who have low income and depressive symptoms with thorough case management may be sufficient for alleviating depressive symptoms, without psychotherapy or other interventions for depression (Areán et al., 2015 ), which has important implications for treatment planning.

sect2.title: Adjusting Assessment Procedures
sect2.para: In addition to assessing a client’s multidimensional needs, the interviewer may need to adjust the assessment process to accommodate these needs. For example, the clinician may need to be flexible regarding time of day and location for meeting, such as if the client has other responsibilities such as work or caregiving, is dependent on others for transportation, or has physical or sensory limitations that limit the ability to travel to certain clinical settings. For a client with communication difficulties, the clinician may want to consider multimodal communication strategies, such as written cues or oral administration of paper-and-pencil questionnaires. For a client with physical limitations, the clinician should inquire about the client’s best time of day and may need to schedule breaks or assessments across multiple time periods.
